allegations.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14040841|publisher=BBC News|title=News of the World 'hacked 7/7 family phones'|date=6 July 2011}} A number of survivors from the bombed trains also revealed that police had warned them their phones may have been accessed and their messages intercepted, and in some cases officers advised them to change security codes and [[Personal identification number|PINs]].{{cite web|last=Hutchinson |first=Lisa |url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/north-east-news/evening-chronicle-news/2011/07/07/tyneside-7-7-bombings-survivor-lisa-french-has-been-contacted-by-detectives-investigating-news-of-the-world-phone-hacking-scandal-72703-29009171/ |title=Tyneside 7/7 bombings survivor Lisa French has been contacted by detectives investigating News of the World phone hacking scandal. |publisher=ChronicleLive |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=16 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201141110/http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/north-east-news/evening-chronicle-news/2011/07/07/tyneside-7-7-bombings-survivor-lisa-french-has-been-contacted-by-detectives-investigating-news-of-the-world-phone-hacking-scandal-72703-29009171/ |archivedate=1 February 2012 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.kentnews.co.uk/news/london_bombing_survivor_threatens_to_sue_over_hacking_1_956554|title=London bombing survivor threatens to sue over hacking|work=Kent News|date=8 July 2011|accessdate=16 September 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812034940/http://www.kentnews.co.uk/news/london_bombing_survivor_threatens_to_sue_over_hacking_1_956554|archivedate=12 August 2011}}{{cite web|author=Susan Ryan|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/warnings-of-potential-irish-victims-of-notw-phone-hacking-172128-Jul2011/|title=Warnings of potential Irish victims of NOTW phone hacking|publisher=Thejournal.ie|date=7 July 2011|accessdate=16 September 2011}} ==Memorials== [[File:TrFlagsmall1b.jpg|thumb|People observing a two-minute silence in [[Trafalgar Square]] on the evening of 14 July 2005]] [[File:7 7 Hyde Park 090712.jpg|thumb|The [[7 July Memorial]] in [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]]]] {{main article|7 July 2005 London bombings memorials and services}} Since the bombings, the United Kingdom and other nations have honoured the victims in several ways. Most of these memorials have included moments of silence, candlelit vigils, and the laying of flowers at the attack sites. Foreign leaders have also remembered the dead by ordering their flags to be flown at [[half-mast]], signing books of condolences at embassies of the UK, and issuing messages of support and condolences to the British people. ===United Kingdom=== The government ordered the [[Union Flag]] to be flown at half-mast on 8 July.(7 July 2005). "[https://web.archive.org/web/20060308171225/http://www.utvlive.com/newsroom/indepth.asp?id=62372&pt=n Union Flag to Fly at Half-Mast]". UTV. Retrieved 4 September 2007. The following day, the [[Bishop of London]] led prayers for the victims during a service paying tribute to the role of women during the Second World War. A vigil, called by the [[Stop the War Coalition]], [[Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]] and [[Muslim Association of Britain]], was held from 5 pm, at Friends Meeting House on Euston Road. A two-minute silence was held on 14 July 2005 throughout Europe.(10 July 2005). "[https://www.theguardian.com/attackonlondon/story/0,16132,1525387,00.html Europe to Mark Tragedy With Two Minutes of Silence]". ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 4 September 2007. Thousands attended a vigil at 6 pm on [[Trafalgar Square]]. After an initial silence there was a series of speakers for two hours. A memorial service was held at [[St Paul's Cathedral]] on 1 November 2005.(1 November 2005). "[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4394062.stm Tributes Paid to Bombing Victims]". BBC. Retrieved 4 September 2007. To mark the first anniversary of the attack, a two-minute silence was observed at midday across the country.(7 July 2006). "[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/5153678.stm Nation Remembers 7 July Victims]". BBC News. Retrieved 4 September 2007. A [[7 July Memorial|permanent memorial was unveiled]] in 2009 by [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]] in [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] to mark the fourth anniversary of the bombings.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8137265.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Tributes paid at 7 July memorial|date=7 July 2009}} On the eve of the ninth anniversary of the attacks in 2014 the memorial was defaced with messages including "Blair lied, thousands died". The graffiti was removed within hours.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/jul/07/july-7-survivors-memorial-defacement-anniversary|title=7/7 survivors condemn defacement of memorial on ninth anniversary|last=Tran|first=Mark|date=7 July 2014|work=The Guardian|accessdate=7 July 2014}} During the [[2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony of the 2012 Olympic Games]] in London a minute's silence was held to commemorate those killed in the attacks. A memorial service was held in St. Paul's Cathedral on 7 July 2015, to mark the 10th anniversary of the bombings. This was broadcast on BBC One.http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b061vc8z ===International=== US President [[George W. Bush]] visited the British embassy the day after the bombings, upon his return from the G8 summit in Scotland, and signed a book of condolence.{{cite web|date=8 July 2005|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2005/07/20050708-9.html|title=President Signs Book of Condolence at British Embassy|publisher=White House|accessdate=16 April 2008}} In Washington, D.C., the US Army band played "[[God Save the Queen]]" (the British national anthem, the melody of which is also used in an American patriotic hymn, "[[My Country, 'Tis of Thee]]"), a suggestion that US Army veteran John Miska made to Vice Chief of Staff General Cody, outside the [[British Embassy, Washington|British embassy in the city]].(7 July 2005). "[http://www.cnn.com/2005/US/07/07/us.response/index.html U.S. raises terror alert for transit systems – 7 July 2005]". CNN. Retrieved 16 April 2008. A similar tribute had been made by the Queen in the days following the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001 where the [[Star Spangled Banner]] played at Buckingham Palace's [[Changing the Guard]].{{cn|date=April 2018}} On 12 July, a [[Detroit Symphony Orchestra]] brass ensemble played the British national anthem during the pre-game festivities of the [[2005 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|Major League Baseball All-Star Game]] at [[Comerica Park]] in Detroit.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/allstar/2005-07-13-rating-the-game_x.htm|title=Rating the game: Clemens, dugout humor spice it up|date=13 July 2005|accessdate=15 January 2010|first=Mike|last=Dodd|newspaper=USA Today}} Flags were ordered to fly at half-mast across Australia, New Zealand(8 July 2005). "[http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/411749/596569 No Known New Zealand Casualties in London]". tvnz.co.nz. Retrieved 4 September 2007. and Canada.(1 September 2005). "[http://www.canadianheritage.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/berne-halfmasting/index_e.cfm Half Masting of the Flag] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051105014751/http://www.canadianheritage.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/berne-halfmasting/index_e.cfm |date=5 November 2005 }}". Canadian Heritage. Retrieved 4 September 2007. The Union Flag was raised to half-mast alongside the [[Flag of Australia]] on [[Sydney Harbour Bridge]] as a show of "sympathy between nations".(3 September 2009). "[http://www.flagaustnat.asn.au/protocol.php]". Australian National Flag Association. Retrieved 6 February 2011. Moments of silence were observed in the [[European Parliament]], the [[Sejm of the Republic of Poland|Polish parliament]] and by the [[Dáil Éireann|Irish parliament]](12 July 2005) "[http://www.taoiseach.gov.ie/index.asp?locID=199&docID=2085 Government Calls for Two Minutes Silence]", and in Cyprus. Department of the Taoiseach. Retrieved 4 September 2007. on 14 July. The British national anthem was played at the changing of the royal guard at [[Plaza de Oriente]] in Madrid in memorial to the victims of the attacks. The ceremony was attended by the British ambassador to Spain and members of the [[Spanish Royal Family]]. After the 2004 Madrid train bombings, the UK had hosted a similar ceremony at [[Buckingham Palace]].(13 July 2005). "[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4679293.stm Spain Royal Guard Honours London]". BBC. Retrieved 4 September 2007. ==Planned anniversary attack== Mohammed Rehman and Sana Ahmed Khan were sentenced to life imprisonment on 29 December 2015 for preparing an act of terrorism, planning to coincide with the tenth anniversary of the 7/7 attacks.{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/silent-bomber-mohammed-rehman-and-wife-sana-ahmed-khan-sentenced-to-life-in-prison-for-london-terror-a6790741.html |title='Silent Bomber' Mohammed Rehman and wife Sana Ahmed Khan sentenced to life in prison for London terror plot |newspaper=The Independent |date=30 December 2015|author=Caroline Mortimer |accessdate= 6 June 2017}} They had 10 kg of [[urea nitrate]]. Rehman called himself the 'silent bomber' and asked his Twitter followers to choose between the [[Westfield Shopping Centre]] or the [[London Underground]] for the planned suicide bomb.{{Cite news|title = Couple found guilty of 7/7 anniversary London bomb plot|url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/29/couple-guilty-july-7-anniversary-bomb-plot-london|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 29 December 2015|access-date = 15 January 2016|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB|first = Owen |last=Bowcott }} ==See also== {{Portal|London|Terrorism|2000s}} * [[September 11 attacks]] * [[2004 Madrid train bombings]] * [[2007 London car bombs]] * [[Death of Jean Charles de Menezes]] * [[Victoria station and Paddington station bombings]] * [[1992 London Bridge bombing]] * [[Aldwych bus bombing]] * [[November 2015 Paris attacks]] * [[2015 Leytonstone tube station attack]] * [[2016 Brussels bombings]] * [[2017 Westminster attack]] * [[Manchester Arena bombing]] * [[2017 London Bridge attack]] * [[Parsons Green bombing]] * [[Murder of Lee Rigby]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== {{Refbegin}} ;Books * {{ISBN|978-1-844675-456}}; [[Tariq Ali|Ali, Tariq]]; ''[[Rough Music: Blair, Bombs, Baghdad, London, Terror]]''; (2005) ;Official reports * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/05_06_06_london_bombing.pdf Greater London Authority report] ''(PDF)'' * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/11_05_06_narrative.pdf House of Commons report] ''(PDF)'' * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/11_05_06_isc_london_attacks_report.pdf Intelligence and Security Committee report – May 2006] ''(PDF)'' * [http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090606014206/http%3A//www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/media/210852/20090519_77review.pdf Intelligence and Security Committee report – May 2009] ''(PDF)'' ;Medical report * [http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/353/6/541?query=TOC The account of the doctor leading the team at the scene of the Tavistock Square bus bomb]. Retrieved 11 August 2005 ;Radio broadcasts; * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio/aod/networks/london/aod.shtml?london/jongaunt_bombings# The Jon Gaunt show]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} originally broadcast live at 9:00 am on 7 July 2005 on [[BBC London]]. First mention of events at approximately 27 minutes into the broadcast. ;Photos * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/spl/hi/uk/05/london_blasts/victims/ Images of the victims] * [http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article324831.ab Swedish newspaper Aftonbladet writes about posters honouring the terrorists] {{Refend}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote-inline|7 July 2005 London bombings}} {{Commons category-inline|London bombing, July 2005}} * [http://julyseventh.co.uk/j7-inquest-transcripts/ Official inquest transcripts] * 2016 [[BBC News]] interview [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-37324130/ with the brother-in-law of Mohammad Sidique Khan] {{London history}} {{2011 News Corporation scandal}} {{DEFAULTSORT:London bombings}} [[Category:Attacks in 2005]] [[Category:2005 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Anwar al-Awlaki]] [[Category:July 2005 London bombings|7 July]] [[Category:Mass murder in 2005]] [[Category:Attacks on_railway stations]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in 2005]] [[Category:Suicide bombings in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:History of the City of London]] [[Category:Massacres in England]] [[Category:Crime in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2005 in London]] [[Category:2005 in rail transport]] [[Category:Disasters on the London Underground]] [[Category:Improvised explosive device bombings in London]] [[Category:Murder in London]] [[Category:Bus bombings]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents on underground rapid transit systems]] [[Category:Islamic terrorist incidents in the 2000s]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in the United Kingdom in 2005]] [[Category:July 2005 crimes]] [[Category:July 2005 events in Europe]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in England]] [[Category:Islam in London]]

{{Chinese |title=Pseudonym |t=號 |s=号 |p=hào |w=hao |l="mark" |shinjitai=号 |kyujitai=號 |kana=ごう ([[Modern kana usage|modern usage]])
がう ([[Historical kana usage|historical usage]]) |romaji=gō |hangul=호 |hanja=號 |rr=ho |mr=ho |hide=no |quoc ngu=hiệu }} {{refimprove|date=September 2016}} A '''pseudonym''' or '''pen name''', also known by its native names '''''hao''''' (in China) ({{zh|s=号}}), '''''gō''''' (in Japan) and '''''ho''''' (in Korea), is a professional name used by [[East Asian]] [[artist]]s. The word and the concept originated in [[China]], then became popular in other [[East Asian]] countries (especially in [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[Vietnam]] and the former [[Kingdom of Ryukyu]]). In some cases, artists adopted different pseudonyms at different stages of their career, usually to mark significant changes in their life. Extreme practitioners of this tendency were [[Tang Yin]] of the [[Ming dynasty]], who had more than ten ''hao'' and [[Hokusai]] of Japan, who in the period 1798 to 1806 alone used no fewer than six. ==History== ===China=== In Chinese culture, the ''hào'' (Traditional 號; Simplified 号) originally refers to any name a person gives oneself, as opposed to a birth name (which is given by the parents or other elders). The use of this name as a nom de plume or artistic name, however, appears to have begun only during the [[Six Dynasties]] period, with [[Tao Yuanming]] and [[Ge Hong]] among the first literati to have given themselves ''hào''. Art names came into vogue during the [[Tang dynasty]], during which time they could either be coined by the person themself, or given to them as a name by others. Most ''hào'' can be placed within a few categories: * ''Hào'' derived from the locations or characteristics of the person's residence. For instance, Tao Yuanming was Wuliu Xiansheng, "Mister Five-Willows", while [[Su Shi]] was Dongpo Jushi, "[[Householder (Buddhism)|Householder]] of the Eastern Slope", after his residence while exiled in [[Huangzhou]]. These were mostly self-coined. * ''Hào'' derived from certain well known sayings by the person. For example, [[Ouyang Xiu]] was known as Liuyi Jushi, "Householder of the Six Ones", after his self description as "One myriad books, one thousand inscriptions, one [[guqin|qin]], one game of chess, one flask of wine and one old man". * ''Hào'' derived from one's famous poetic lines or images. These were most often given by others in admiration. [[Li Bai]], for his free-spirited behaviour, was known as Zhe Xianren, "Banished Immortal"; while the poet [[He Zhu]] was known as He Meizi, "He the Plum", after an acclaimed line about yellow plums. * ''Hào'' derived from one's official posts, birthplace, or a place where they served as officials. [[Du Fu]] was known as Du Gongbu, "Du of the Ministry of Works", having briefly been a senior officer in that ministry. [[Tang Xianzu]] was called "Tang of Nanhai" for his birthplace. By the [[Song Dynasty]], the majority of literati called each other by their art names, which in turn often changed; this situation continued up to the 20th century.http://tieba.baidu.com/p/658776377 ===Japan=== {{unreferenced section|date=September 2016}} In [[Edo period|early modern]] Japan, a [[ukiyo-e|woodblock print]] artist's first ''gō'' was usually given to them by the head of the school (a group of artists and apprentices, with a senior as master of the school) in which they initially studied; this ''gō'' usually included one of the characters of the master's ''gō''. For example, one of Hokusai's earliest pseudonyms was Shunrō; his master [[Katsukawa Shunshō]] having granted him the character 'shun' from his own name. One can often trace the relationship among artists with this, especially in later years, when it seems to have been fairly (although not uniformly) systematic (particularly in the [[Utagawa school]]) that the first character of the pupil's ''gō'' was the last of the master's ''gō''. Thus, an artist named [[Utagawa Toyoharu|Toyoharu]] had a student named [[Utagawa Toyohiro|Toyohiro]], who, in turn, had as a pupil the famous landscape artist [[Hiroshige]]. Another figure who studied under Toyoharu was the principal head of the [[Utagawa school]], [[Utagawa Toyokuni|Toyokuni]]. Toyokuni had pupils named [[Utagawa Kunisada|Kunisada]] and [[Utagawa Kuniyoshi|Kuniyoshi]]. Kuniyoshi, in turn, had as a student [[Utagawa Yoshitoshi|Yoshitoshi]], whose pupils included Toshikata. ==Reused names== {{unreferenced section|date=September 2016}} In some schools, in particular the main Utagawa school,{{citation needed|date=July 2009}} the ''gō'' of the most senior member was adopted when the master died and the chief pupil assumed his position. Perhaps as a sign of respect, artists might take the ''gō'' of a previous artist. This makes attribution difficult. The censors' seal helps determine a particular print's date. Style also is significant. For example, Kunisada, once he changed his ''gō'' to Toyokuni, initiated the practice of signing prints with a signature in the elongated oval ''toshidama'' ('New Year's Jewel') seal of the Utagawa school, an unusual [[cartouche]] with the zig-zag in the upper right-hand corner. His successors continued this practice. In modern scholarship on the subject, a Roman numeral identifies an artist in the sequence of artists using a ''gō''. Thus, Kunisada I is also known as Toyokuni III, since he was the third artist to use that ''gō''. ==See also== *[[Courtesy name]] ==References== {{reflist}} *Frederic, Louis (2002). "Gō". ''Japan Encyclopedia''. Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press. *Lane, Richard (1978). ''Images of the Floating World''. Old Saybrook, CT: Konecky & Konecky. {{Personal names}} [[Category:Chinese culture]] [[Category:Japanese artists]] [[Category:Pseudonyms]]

{{Other uses|Miani (disambiguation)}} {{Multiple issues| {{lead too short|date=November 2011}} {{POV check|date=February 2012}} {{More citations needed|date=May 2016}} }} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Miani |image=Battle of Miani.jpg |caption= |partof= the conquest of Sindh |date=February 17, 1843 |place=[[Miani, Sindh|Miani]] |result=[[East India Company]] victory |combatant1=[[Image:Flag of the British East India Company (1707).svg|22x25px]] [[Bombay Army]] of the [[East India Company]] |combatant2= [[Talpur]] [[Emir]]s of [[Sindh]] |commander1=Maj. Gen. [[Charles James Napier|Charles Napier]] |commander2=[[Mir Nasir Khan Talpur]] |units1 = [[N Battery (The Eagle Troop) Royal Horse Artillery|1st Troop Bombay Horse Artillery]],
[[Bombay Light Horse|9th Bombay Light Horse]],
[[112th Infantry|12th Bombay Native Infantry]],
[[121st Pioneers|21st Bombay Native Infantry]],
[[125th Napier's Rifles|25th Bombay Native Infantry]],
[[Cheshire Regiment|22nd Cheshire Regiment of foot]],
[[Poona Horse|Poona Irregular Horse]] |units2 = |strength1=2,800Sir Charles James Napier - Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition |strength2= 30,000 |casualties1=39 dead, 231 wounded |casualties2=~2000 dead |}} The '''Battle of Miani''' (or '''Battle of Meeanee''') was a battle between forces of the [[Bombay Army]] of the British East India company, under [[Charles James Napier|Charles Napier]] and the Baluch army of [[Talpur]] [[Emir|Amirs]] of [[Sindh]], led by [[Mir Nasir Khan Talpur]]. The Battle took place on 17 February 1843 at [[Miani, Sindh]], in what is now Pakistan. This battle eventually led to the capture of parts of Sindh region, first territorial possession by British East India company in what is the modern-day country of [[Pakistan]]. ==Background==
According to Nadeem Wagan (a Sindh writer), the primary causes of the battle were the British East India company's desire to expand their possession in south Asia and the British General [[Charles James Napier|Charles Napier]]'s ambitions. The General had held previous position as Governor of the Greek island of Kefalonia with very limited scope for glory. The [[Talpur dynasty|Talpur]] kingdom of Sindh was inefficiently and loosely governed by the [[Amir]]s and a relatively easy target as opposed to the [[Sikh]] kingdom of the [[Punjab region|Punjab]]. Napier moved his army aggressively from the [[East India Company]]'s [[Bombay presidency]] area and entered the Sindh border. Negotiations ensued between the Talpur Amir in [[Hyderabad, Sindh|Hyderabad]] and Napier. An agreement was reached after the Amir gave significant concessions. Napier then started to move his army back towards Bombay and the Amir disbanded his army that had been mobilised. However, Napier was firmly determined in conquering Sindh and Hyderabad. Whilst moving towards Bombay and giving the impression of keeping the agreement that had been reached, he suddenly turned back towards Hyderabad on the pretext of hostile intentions by the Amir and marched with great speed towards the capital. In the book Janat ul Sindh, Rahimdad Khan Molai Shedai has written that,
"On 16 February 1843 Sir Charles Napier came to Matiari from Hala.He was commanding 2800 soldiers with 12 canonns.On the other side Balouch army was consisted of 2200 soldiers with 15 cannons.Army of Sindh began to gather at the bank of Phuleli near Miani but there was no sufficient arrangements for providing ammunition to the army. English army was consisted of soldiers belonging to Bombay,Pune and Madras.Charles Napier was commander and his subordinates were captain John Jackab, captain Hutt, major Jackson, lieutenant Weddington, Major Penny Father, lieutenant Mac Merdo (Aide de camp of Napier), Major Wylie, Captain Tucker,Lieutinant Colonel Patel, Major Stori, captain Thomas, Major Machozison (Secretary of Napier), Capt. Wemus, Capt. Cookson,lieutenant Marston,Capt. Garrett were his subordinates. The Talpur army was composed of Shahdadani, Chakrani, and Khanani Talpurs. Bijrani and Muhammadani Talpurs did not join. Mir Naseer had sent message to Malak Ibrahim Khan,the Sardar of Kalmati tribe to attack upon English army with the help of Nomri and Jokhiya tribes.The Kalmati Sardar left with band of 400 warriors but Jam Khan,Sardar of Jokhiya and Nomri tribes did not join him hence Ibrahim Khan went back to home. Mankani tribe also did not join. However Balochi tribes Nizamani, Bagrani, Mari, Jamali, Chang, Gopang, Jatoi, Qarai, Rind, Lashari, Bhurgri, and Chuulgri joined the army. In addition to Balouch tribes Khokhar, Khatiyan, Soomra, Khaskhali, and many others gathered under the banner of Sindh. Sadaat of Sindh also joined the army with fervor of Jihad. Mir Jan Muhammad Khanani was commander of army. His subordinates were Mir Ghulam Shah Shahwani, Syed Abdullah, Ibrahim Khan, Nawab Ahmed Khan Lighari, Ghulam Muhammad Lighari, Bakhtiyar Khan, Bahawal Khan Rind, Moro Khan Chang and Syed Fateh Muhammad Shah Lakiyari, who were warlords. Mir Ghulam Shah was Vice Commander. Hosh Muhammad Qambrani negro, Mashedi Irani and Mr Hawel were in charge of Talpur artillery. The army of Meers' was seven times larger than English army but their weapons were imperfect as compare to the weapons of the rivals. English army was well trained but Talpur army was untrained and lacking discipline. The cannons of Meers' were three feet long and diameter of their muzzles was three inches. Their guns were breech-loaders of old times. English soldiers, including local soldiers, were active and clever because of discipline having support of medical staff for providing first aid. Their army was supported by traveling band for providing ammunition and for digging tranches. Both armies were at the distance of 100 yards from each other. Mir Naseer Khan was wearing armor. Mir Rustam Khan, Mir Hussain Ali Khan and Mir Shahdad Khan were at his right and left sides. Both banks of Phuleli canal were covered by dense bushes which could be used for defense of the army. By that time Phuleli canal was dry and very wide. The chief of Chandia tribe was at some distance with 10000 warriors waiting and alert for the help of English army.On 17 February 1843 at early morning battle started".Rahimdad Khan Molai Shedai; Janat ul Sindh, 3rd edition 1993,pages no 737-739; Sindhi Adbi Board Jamshoro
==Battle== The Baluch were forced to quickly re-mobilise their army but could not do so effectively as the army was mostly raised on a voluntary basis in times of war and most of the Baluch had returned home. Nevertheless, an army of around 8,000 - mostly cavalry - was raised and assembled at the battle ground of Miani. Disastrously for the Talpur Amirs another 8,000 troops under [[Mir Sher Muhammad Talpur]] (later known as ''Sher-e-Sindh'' or "Lion of Sindh") failed to reach the battle ground in time. Napier had already successfully isolated the [[Amir]] of [[Khayrpur (princely state)|Khairpur]] (thereafter known as the great traitor by the Sindhi) by bribery and title. Thus the Baluchi army assembled at Miani represented approximately a third of the potential military strength in Sindh. Although the East India Company later gave its troops numbered in the battle as around 2,800, contemporary Talpur records indicated the armies were approximately equal in numbers (around 8–10 thousand each) with the British having around 2,500 European officers and soldiers and the balance being Indian [[sepoys]]. The difference in military technology and tactics was enormous. The East India Company's army was led by professionally trained British officers and troops and the Indian Sepoys were also well trained and disciplined. They were armed with smoothbore percussion or [[flintlock]] [[Brown Bess]] [[musket]]s, which were accurate to 50–100 yards, and supported by modern artillery. In contrast, the Baluchi army consisted mostly of cavalry armed with muskets, spears and swords and some old artillery pieces acquired from [[Persia]]. The tactic was the favoured cavalry charge. Contemporary records indicate that the Baluchi army's morale was very high with the battle slogan being "we will die but not give up Sindh". Indeed, the Baluchis died in thousands, in 4–5 hours of carnage, the Baluchi horsemen charged in wave after wave and was mostly cut down long before they could reach British lines by rifle and artillery fire. When they did eventually reach British lines and, according to Napier himself in his book on the battle (''Conquest of Sindh''), he had to ride amongst his officers and troops to stop them from falling back in disarray in the face of the ferocity of the Baluch who had reached the British lines. Of the Baluch army of 8,000 at Miani, around 6 thousand Baluch were killed. Reliable sources put the British casualties as 256''The History of British India: A Chronology'' by John F. Riddick as kept by the East India company's paymasters while according to the Baluch, the Company's army suffered 3,000 dead (although Napier gives a much lower casualty figure as he does for his total force). In famous book on history of Sindh 'Jannat ul Sindh' Molai Shedai writes that."At the time of start of war at early morning at first one band of English army moved a head into the battle feild so that the hidden part of Talpur army might come out of the bushes"."At beginning Mir Jan Muhammad fought with stretegy and Charles Napier was sure of defeat. English cavalry bands attacked from right and left sides and Mir Jan Muhammad was martyred and Mir Ghulam Shah took over the command.John Jackab leading 1000 cavalry attacked through the bed of Phuleli canal and at once moved back with deception and Talpur army thought it retreat and their lines stood broken and they followed the cavalry and reached across the banks of Phuleli where English artillery was staged at hidden place and English army opened the artillery upon them continuously for three hours .One cannonball hit against the ammunition of Talpur army which was completely destroyed.After noon time one band of Ligharis was retreated then Thorha then Bahawal Khan ran from battlefield who was followed by Nawab Ahmed Lighari who also snatched the flag from Soomar before leaving the battlefield. Mir Naseer and Shahdad wanted to fight till last breath but their army was fleeing from battlefield .About 4000 were among them who left away without any order.One cannonball fall nearby and Suleman, personal servant of the Meer was martyred.It appeared that army of Meers was under siege. Chang, Gopang, Mari and Nizamani were still fighting in battlefield. English army took control of the artillery of Meers due to support of one of in charge of the artillery who was Mr Hawel.At one moment Charles Napier came under attack but was saved by Lieuftenant Marston.At last moments Mir Hussain Ali Khan also ran away from battlefield. Looking to the situation Mir Naseer Khan also left the battlefield along with 1200 cavalry and came at the Fort of Hyderabad.During 3 hours face to face battle only 27 soldiers of English Army were died and became injured. From officers Major Tezdil, Major Jackson, Captain Maddy, Captain Tieve, Captain Cookson, Lieuftenant Wood were died and Lieutenant Penny Father, Major Welly, Captain Tucker, Captain Convey, Lieuftenant Harding and Feri became injured. About 20 British officers died and 4 officers from infantry were amongst them. About 5000 from Talpurs'army died. Mir Jan Muhammad Khan,Talha khan Nizamani, Ghulam Hussain khan Nizamani, Abdullah Khan, Ali Bungash,Gohar Khan Hajizai, Naseer Khan Chang,Mir Ghulam Shah,Mir Mubarak Khan Bihrani and others were among them. During 3 hours battle only one Irish soldier could stab bayonet at the chest of one Balouch soldier who was also killed by the other with sword as dead bodies of the both were found together. Captain Postins in his book 'Personal observation of Sindh' while mentioning about battle of Miani wrote that' People of Sindh fought against the English army like persons who may fight for something which is more dearer to them than their lives'.Rahimdad Khan Molai Shedai; Janat ul Sindh,3rd edition 1993, pages no:339 to 342; Sindhi Adbi Board Jamshoro Later, on March 24, 1843, [[Mir Sher Muhammad Talpur|Mir Sher Muhammad Khan Talpur]], reached [[Hyderabad, Sindh|Hyderabad]] with his private army of around 8,000 and tried to liberate Sindh from the occupation of the [[British East India Company]] forces. He sent Napier a message giving the General 48 hours to vacate the Hyderabad Fort. Napier who was firmly entrenched in Hyderabad Fort and had recently been reinforced from Bombay replied by firing his artillery from the Fort walls. Mir Sher Muhammad Khan Talpur was subsequently defeated in the [[Battle of Dubba]] and thereafter he went to Punjab to seek help from Maharaja Ranjeet Singh, the Sikh ruler of the Punjab. The Maharaja extended hospitality but declined to become involved. Sher Muhammad Khan then went to the Khan of Kalat to seek assistance, but the Khanate of Kalat had already suffered a defeat by the British in 1838 and was in no position to help. Eventually after 10 years, Mir Sher Muhammad returned to Sindh and surrendered to the British and the East India Company gave him amnesty. The [[amir]]s of Hyderabad suffered great loss, their fort was plundered, and amirs themselves were exiled to Andaman Islands – never to see Sindh again. Napier's post-conquest occupation of Sindh was absolute. Fifteen years later when the [[Indian Mutiny]] or 'War of Independence' in 1857 broke out, no shots were fired in Sindh. His manipulations of the history of his interactions with the [[Talpur dynasty]] and the history of the battle were likewise absolute and designed to glorify his position. However, debates that took place in the [[British Parliament]] for the post-conquest show the degree of concern that existed in UK on the action he had taken in Sindh. The battle honours of "Meeanee" and "Hyderabad" are shared by the [[22nd (Cheshire) Regiment]] and a number of Indian regiments, whereas that of "Scinde" is borne by the Cheshire Regiment alone. ==Casualties== Five thousand [[Sindhi people|Sindhi]]s were killed or wounded while fighting the British.[http://dsal.uchicago.edu/reference/gazetteer/pager.html?objectid=DS405.1.I34_V17_321.gif Miāni - ''Imperial Gazetteer of India'', v. 17, p. 315.] The fallen Amirs of Sindh consisted of [[Mir Nasir Khan Talpur]], his nephews [[Mir Shadad Khan Talpur]], [[Mir Hussein Ali Khan Talpur]], [[Mir Sher Muhammad Talpur]], the [[Subedar]] of [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], [[Mir Rustam Khan Talpur]], [[Nasir Talpur]], [[Wali Mohammad Khan Talpur]] of [[Khairpur, Pakistan|Khairpur]]. Others such as [[Mir Ali Murad Khan Talpur]] was taken aboard the sloop {{HMS|Nimrod}} and exiled to [[Burma]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=Fl6qYIcln8MC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Debal&as_brr=1&source=gbs_book_similarbooks#v=onepage&q=&f=false Personal observations on Sindh: the manners and customs of its inhabitants; and its productive capabilities] A British journal said of the captive Sindhi Amirs: "The Amirs as being the prisoners of the state are maintained in strict seclution; they are described as Broken-Hearted and Miserable men, maintaining much of the dignity of fallen greatness, and without any querulous or angry complainngs at this unalleviable source of sorrow, refusing to be comforted". ==References== ;Notes {{reflist}} ;Bibliography * {{London Gazette |issue=20212 |date=11 April 1843 |pages=1193–1195 }} Dispatches from Major-General Sir Charles Napier, KCB * {{London Gazette |issue=20231 |date=6 June 1843 |pages=1893–1895 }} Dispatches from Major-General Sir Charles Napier, KCB {{History of Sindh}} {{coord missing|Pakistan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Battle Of Miani}} [[Category:Conflicts in 1843]] [[Category:Battles involving the United Kingdom|Miani 1843]] [[Category:History of Sindh]] [[Category:Military history of Sindh]] [[Category:February 1843 events]] [[Category:Talpur dynasty]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} A '''bedspace apartment''' ({{zh|牀位寓所}}), also called '''cage home''' ({{zh|t=籠屋|labels=no}}), '''coffin cubicle''', or '''coffin home''', is a type of [[Residential area|residence]] that is only large enough for one bunk bed surrounded by a metal cage.<ref>Hong Kong People's Council on Housing Policy. 熱窩(住屋權報告書). Step Forward Multi Media, 2000, p.23</ref> In 2007, there were approximately 53,200 people living in cage homes.<ref>"[http://socialindicators.org.hk/en/indicators/housing/8.11 Social Indicators of Hong Kong: Number of persons living in cage housing]". Retrieved 2013-3-31.</ref> This type of [[Residential area|residence]] originated in Hong Kong, and primarily exists in older urban districts such as [[Sham Shui Po]], [[Mong Kok]], [[To Kwa Wan]], and [[Tai Kok Tsui]].
Generally, the residents are low-income people, including the elderly, drug addicts, and some low-skilled or unskilled labourers.<ref>[http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20110916/15618628 Apple Daily, 2011-09-16].</ref> Reports from the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|Legislative Council]] of Hong Kong found that the people who lived in cage homes were those who did not qualify for [[social welfare]], or [[subsidy|subsidised]] rent or electricity.<ref name="legco">[http://www.legco.gov.hk/yr07-08/chinese/panels/hg/papers/hg0310cb1-971-1-c.pdf] #籠屋、板房及套房 租住問題研究報告, 2008.</ref> Most of the residents are male. Safety and other living conditions in bedspace apartments homes are often poor.
==Official definition== While often called cage homes, they are categorised as "bedspace apartments" by the [[Hong Kong Government]]. According to the Bedspace Apartment Ordinance, the term "bedspace apartment" refers to a house that contains 12 or more people who rent bedspaces individually. It is legal to run these bedspace apartments, but landlords must first apply for a special license.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bedspace Apartments Ordinance |url=http://www.hadla.gov.hk/en/bedspace/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bedspace Apartments Ordinance|url=http://www.legislation.gov.hk/blis_pdf.nsf/4f0db701c6c25d4a4825755c00352e35/5D36F89C913B3600482575EF0008BCC1/$FILE/CAP_447_e_b5.pdf}}</ref>
==History== Bedspace apartments started to appear more commonly during the 1950s and 60s. During the [[Chinese Civil War]], a large number of Chinese mainlanders migrated to Hong Kong, and this, along with a surge in birth rates due to the prospering economy, caused the population to dramatically increase from 2,015,300 in 1951 to 3,129,648 in 1961.<ref>Hong Kong Annual Report. 1962. Population. p. 36.</ref> In an attempt to cope with the housing demand, the [[Hong Kong Government]] started to build several public housing estates. However, the government could not handle the extra burden brought by the Chinese [[migrant worker]]s, and there were no housing or labour protection policies in place at that time. Cage homes thus became popular among migrant workers, as the rental fee was low.<ref> (2008) [http://www.soco.org.hk/cagehome2008/cage_bkg.htm#history Society for Community Organization. What is a "Caged Home"?]</ref>
Today, people still live in cage homes because the Hong Kong government has instituted a single-person scoring system for public housing applications and lowered public housing quotas. In addition, according to the [[Hong Kong Basic Law]], new immigrants must wait 7 years to become [[Hong Kong permanent resident]]s. As such, poor immigrants are often forced to live in bedspace apartments until they receive a [[Hong Kong Identity Card|Hong Kong ID card]].<ref name="legco" />
== Cage hotels in the United States {{anchor|Cage hotel}}== '''Cage hotels''', a form of [[single room occupancy]], were common in [[Chicago]] at the turn of the 20th century; an estimated 40,000 to 60,000 people lived in them during the winter.
{{quote|These were lofts or other large, open buildings that were subdivided into tiny [[cubicle]]s using boards or sheets of [[Corrugated galvanised iron|corrugated iron]]. Since these walls were always one to three feet short of the floor or ceiling, the open space was sealed off with [[chicken wire]], hence the name “cage hotels."<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia | title = Single Room Occupancy Hotels | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia of Chicago]] | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | url = http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/613.html }}</ref>}}
A 1958 survey by [[Christopher Jencks]] found that homeless men preferred cage hotels over [[Homeless shelter|shelters]] for reasons of privacy and security.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Christopher Jencks | title = Housing the Homeless | work = [[The New York Review of Books]] | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | url = http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1994/may/12/housing-the-homeless/ }}</ref>
A similar preference for cage hotels over shelters was reported in turn of the century [[New York City]], where single working men ranked their housing preference in the following order:
{{quote|They preferred lodging and [[boarding house]]s to cages, cages to [[Dormitory|dormitories]], dormitories to flops, and flops to the city’s shelters. Men could act on these preferences by moving as their incomes increased.<ref>{{Cite news |issue = Summer |last = Filer |first = Randall K |authorlink = Randall K. Filer |title = Opening the Door to Low-Cost Housing |work = [[City Journal (New York)|City Journal]] |accessdate = 2013-02-13 |date = 1992 |url = http://www.city-journal.org/article01.php?aid=1529 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120620080305/http://www.city-journal.org/article01.php?aid=1529 |archivedate = 2012-06-20 |df = }}</ref>}}
"Regulatory efforts to combat low-cost 'cage hotels,' ... [has been] a driver of the expansion of the [[Homelessness in the United States|homeless population in US cities]]", according to Jencks.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Reihan Salam | title = The Agenda: Stephen Smith on the Missing Driverless Trains | work = [[National Review|National Review Online]] | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | url = http://www.nationalreview.com/agenda/309617/stephen-smith-missing-driverless-trains-reihan-salam?toggle=y }}</ref>
==Environment== Bedspace apartments are usually located inside old buildings in urban areas. In the apartment flats, the whole living space is divided into multiple sections. Each section has two to three layers of beds, which are subdivided with metal cages. With no doors, residents have to keep all of their personal belongings inside the confined space. Each bedspace is very narrow, so an adult can barely lie down, stand, or sit straight. Since residents do not have room for any extra personal belongings inside the cage home, such a bedspace is deemed to be a place for sleeping only. Cage homes are dim, cramped, and hot. The temperature can reach 34 degrees Celsius (93 degrees [[Fahrenheit]]).<ref>CNN.(2009) [http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/10/28/cage.homes/index.html Living in a cage in Hong Kong].</ref> Residents share the toilets and kitchen, which are notoriously smelly, dirty, and very simple.<ref>Hong Kong People's Council on Housing Policy. 熱窩(住屋權報告書). (2000) Step Forward Multi Media, p. 25</ref>
Cage homes also lack privacy because the cages are so close to each other. Even though some modern cage homes have partitions to separate different sections, these typically consist of only a thin piece of wood or paper board.
===Safety=== Cage homes generally have poor safety, due to their location within old buildings and inadequate fire protection.
In 1998, the government set up the Bedspace Apartment Ordinance (Section 18: Precautions for Safety and Sanitation) to regulate fire safety standards and requirements. Nevertheless, licensed cage homes are still located in worn-out buildings which lack [[smoke detector]]s, [[Automatic sprinkler|automatic sprinkler systems]] and [[fire alarm system]]s. Worse still, many residents share only one electrical outlet. [[Electric shocks]] and [[Leakage (electronics)|leakage]] frequently occur since the government does not conduct regular inspections to ensure that the various safety measures are up to standard.
In addition, the Bedspace Apartment Ordinance does not regulate unlicensed cage home apartments or other similar residences that do not fulfill the requirements of being a "bedspace apartment." Thus, these unlicensed cage home apartments do not have sufficient safety equipment.
===Hygiene=== Because residents rarely clean the open areas, cage homes are often found to have [[flies]], [[mosquitoes]], mice, and [[cockroaches]]. As such, the filthy environment becomes a breeding ground for bacteria, [[viruses]], and diseases. Metal cages are typically made of iron, which rusts easily.
===Limited space=== Since cage homes are often located within older urban districts, they are usually extremely small. Such space is only suitable for people to take a rest, thus preventing any additional recreational activities. It is observed that an average of 6 to 12 people typically share a cage home apartment. Under the confined and crowded space, cage homes often have poor [[Ventilation (architecture)|ventilation systems]].<ref name= >''[https://web.wpi.edu/Pubs/E-project/Available/E-project-022713-213142/unrestricted/Subdivided_Housing_Issues_of_Hong_Kong_Causes_and_Solutions.pdf Subdivided Housing Issues of Hong Kong: Causes and Solutions: an Interactive Qualifying Project],'' p.11. Daniel Dwan, Meghan Sawicki and Jeffery Wong. [[Worcester Polytechnic Institute]]. Sponsoring agency [[Hong Kong Institute of Education]]. Submitted 2013-02-28. Retrieved 2017-06-02.</ref> Residents are highly susceptible to [[Respiratory disease|respiratory illness]]. In addition, residents (especially the elderly and disabled) find it difficult to evacuate the building in an emergency.
===Psychological well-being=== People who live in cage homes are often victims of destitution. The effect of living in such dilapidated, isolated, and cramped quarters can lead to a higher incidence of mental illness. Some elderly people have described their lives in cage homes as "waiting for death."<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rkTHlo845rM Apple Daily]. 2011-09-16.</ref>
==Social response== According to the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] and the [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]] proposed by the United Nations, cage homes violate the [[right to housing]].{{cn|date=March 2014}}
Many of Hong Kong's citizens and social organisations have urged the government to construct more [[Public housing in Hong Kong|public housing estates]] to replace cage homes for low-income people. The government insists that cage homes should not be eradicated, as there is such a large demand for small apartments in the community.
The 1992 film ''[[Cageman]]'', directed by [[Jacob Cheung]], demonstrates the harsh living conditions in cage homes and sheds light on the difficulties faced by residents.
===News response=== The ''[[Daily Mail]]'' described the cage home as the "dark side" of the otherwise wealthy Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cage dogs of Hong Kong: The tragedy of tens of thousands living in 6ft by 2ft rabbit hutches - in a city with more Louis Vuitton shops than Paris|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2084971/Hong-Kongs-cage-homes-Tens-thousands-living-6ft-2ft-rabbit-hutches.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail|first=Damien|last=Gayle|date=2012-01-11}}</ref>
[[CNN]] has also reported and commented on the living environment of cage homes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hong Kong cage home recession |url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/#/video/business/2009/10/28/yoon.hkong.cage.home.recession.cnn?iref=videosearch | publisher=CNN}}</ref> It described cage homes as the "size of a shoe box,"<ref>{{cite news|title=Living In a cage in Hong Kong |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/10/28/cage.homes/index.html | publisher=CNN | date=2009-10-28}}</ref> and reported that it was difficult for the rest of the world to believe that such a large number of people are living in such poor accommodations in a so-called wealthy city.<ref>{{cite web|title=CNN News Story about cage homes in Hong Kong |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D5hlF2RYdY0}}</ref>
The [[Hong Kong Legislative Council]] published a report about the problem of cage homes in 2008. The report offered some solutions to the problems of cage homes.<ref name="legco" />
==See also== * [[Capsule hotel]] * [[Subdivided flat]]
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rxmo6OZ1McQ Living in a cage in Hong Kong] by Eunice Yoon for [[CNN]] in 2009 on Youtube * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQkvI_J8_QI Squalid Living Conditions Of Hong Kong's Poor Population] by [[SBS Australia]] on Journeyman Pictures on Youtube in 2016 * {{cite news|last1=Haas|first1=Benjamin|title=My week in Lucky House: the horror of Hong Kong's coffin homes|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/29/hong-kong-coffin-homes-horror-my-week|accessdate=26 November 2017|work=The Guardian|date=29 August 2017}} * {{cite news|last1=Scimecca|first1=Alex|title=Inside Hong Kong's 50 Sq. Ft. 'Coffin Cubicle' Homes|url=http://fortune.com/2017/11/01/hong-kong-coffin-cubicle-home/|accessdate=26 November 2017|work=[[Fortune Magazine]]|date=2 November 2017}} * [https://www.flickr.com/search/?text=cage%20home%20hong%20kong Cage homes in Hong Kong] on [[Flickr]]

revision.text:
[[Image:IMac Bondi Blue.jpg|thumb|Apple [[iMac]]]] [[Image:Volkswagen-NewBeetle.jpg|thumb|[[Volkswagen New Beetle]]]] [[File:Blob Birmingham.jpg|thumb|The [[Selfridges]] building ("The Blob") in [[Birmingham]] by architect Jan Kaplicky of [[Future Systems]]]]
A '''blobject''' is a design product, often a household object, distinguished by smooth flowing curves, bright colors, and an absence of sharp edges. The word is generally held to be a [[portmanteau]], a contraction of "blob" and "object."
The origin of the term is disputed, but it is often attributed to either the designer-author Steven Skov Holt<ref name="Skov">[http://www.cca.edu/academics/faculty/sholt CA College of the Arts Bio on Steven Skov Holt]</ref> or the designer [[Karim Rashid]]. Author and design journalist Phil Patton<ref name="Phil">[http://www.randomhouse.com/author/results.pperl?authorid=23367 Random House Bio of Phil Patton]</ref> attributed the word to Holt in 1993 in [[Esquire magazine]]. Holt has defined a blobject as, most often, a colorful, [[mass-produced]], [[plastic]]-based, emotionally engaging [[consumer product]] with a curvilinear, flowing shape. This fluid and curvaceous form is the blobject's most distinctive feature. Rashid, the contemporary designer who wrote the book ''I want to Change the World,'' was an early leader in creating blobjects and has become one of the most celebrated designers of his generation.
Blobjects can also be found in most areas of contemporary [[visual culture]]. * A blobject can be a typographic font (cf. [[Neville Brody]]), an animation (cf. Monica Peon), a piece of furniture ([[Marc Newson]]), an article of clothing ([[Rei Kawakubo]]), a motorcycle (GK Dynamics), a car (GEMCAR), a building ([[Future Systems]]), a painting ([[Rex Ray]]), a piece of sculpture (Hadeki Matsumoto), or ceramics work (Ken Price). * Blobjects can be made of any material in any size or scale for the home, office, car, or outdoors. Common materials used in fabricating blobjects are plastic (especially [[polycarbonate]], [[polypropylene]], or [[polyethylene]]), [[metal]], and [[rubber]], with the aim being to give a more organic and animate feel.
The blobject trend has largely been driven by advances in [[computer-aided design]], [[information visualization]], [[rapid prototyping]], [[materials science|materials]], and [[injection molding]]. These technologies have given designers the chance to use new shapes and to explore transparency and translucency without significant extra production costs.
More recently, in 2004, author [[Bruce Sterling]] used the word in the title of his keynote speech at Siggraph.<ref name="BlobjectsRule">[http://www.siggraph.org/s2004/media/releases/release6.php?pageID=media Siggraph 2004]</ref> In his speech titled, "When Blobjects Rule the Earth", Sterling speculated on the future of graphic simulation when practical differences no longer exist between computer generated models and physically manufactured objects.
==Examples of blobjects== * [[Apple Inc.]] [[iMac G3]] [[computer]] * [[Volkswagen Beetle]] * [[Gillette Mach3]] razor * [[Oral-B]] [[toothbrush]] * [[Swatch]] Twinphone
==See also== * [[Blobitecture]] * [[Greg Lynn]] * [[Ken Rinaldo]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Sterling, Bruce, (2002). ''Tomorrow Now: Envisioning the next fifty years'', Random House, {{ISBN|978-0-679-46322-1}} * Skov Holt, Steven; Holt Skov, Mara, (2005). ''Blobjects & Beyond: The New Fluidity in Design'', Chronicle Books, {{ISBN|978-0-8118-4765-0}} * Rashid, Karim, (2001). ''I Want to Change the World'', Universe Publishing, {{ISBN|978-0-7893-0531-2}}
==External links== * [[Boing Boing]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20041208122248/http://www.boingboing.net/images/blobjects.htm When Blobjects Rule the Earth] by [[Bruce Sterling]] * [http://www.karimrashid.com/ Karim Rashid] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050403195250/http://www.sjmusart.org/blobjects/ San Jose Museum of Art] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050405023049/http://www.cca.edu/academics/industrialdesign/faculty.php Industrial design]
[[Category:Technology in society]] [[Category:Consumer goods]] [[Category:Words coined in the 1990s]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Circassians in Iran |population = Precise population unknown due to heavy assimilation and lack of censuses based on ethnicity.<ref name="mcha.kbsu.ru">{{cite web|url=http://mcha.kbsu.ru/english/m_hist_01E.htm.html|title=International Circassian Association|accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="books.google.nl">[https://books.google.nl/books?id=stl97FdyRswC&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141&dq=number+of+circassians+in+iran&source=bl&ots=u_SmExfuC8&sig=2lK8k9IsUQZyjCtdKqIAIr6Rc5M&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwBDgKahUKEwins7Whz4vGAhVRCNsKHb9pAME#v=onepage&q=number%20of%20circassians%20in%20iran&f=false ''Encyclopedia of the Peoples of Africa and the Middle East''] Facts On File, Incorporated {{ISBN|978-1438126760}} p 141</ref><ref>Fredrik Thordarson, “Caucasus ii. Language contact. Caucasian languages in Iran,” EIr. V, 1990, pp. 94-95.</ref> Second largest Caucasus-derived group in the nation.<ref name="books.google.nl"/> |popplace = [[Tehran]], [[Gilan Province]], [[Mazandaran Province]], [[Rasht]], [[East Azerbaijan Province]], [[Fars Province]],<ref name="ČARKAS">{{cite web|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/carkas-cherkes-term-used-in-persian-arabic-and-turkic-for-the-circassian-people-of-the-northwest-caucasus-who-call-thems|title=ČARKAS|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> [[Isfahan]], [[Aspas, Fars|Aspas]] |langs = Mainly [[Persian language|Persian]], as well as [[Circassian language|Circassian]] in small amounts |rels = [[Islam|Muslim]] |related = }}
The '''[[Circassians]] in Iran''' ([[Kabardian language|East Circassian]] and [[Adyghe language|West Circassian]]: Адыгэхэр Къажэрей, ''Adyghexer Kŭazhéreĭ''; {{lang-fa| چرکس های ایران}}) are an ethnic minority in Iran. Circassians in Iran differ somewhat from other Circassians in diaspora in that most in the former stem from the [[Safavids|Safavid]] and [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar]] era, although a number migrated [[Ethnic cleansing of Circassians|as muhajirs in the late 19th century]] as well. The Circassians in Iran were very influential during periods in the last few centuries. The vast majority of them have assimilated to Persian language, and no sizeable number speaks their native [[Circassian languages]] anymore.<ref name="mcha.kbsu.ru"/> Once a very large minority in Iran, nowadays due to being heavily assimilated over the course of time and the lack of censuses based on ethnicity, population estimates vary significantly. They are, after the [[Iranian Georgians|Georgians]], the largest Caucasus-derived group in the nation.
In Persian, the word ''Cherkes'' ({{lang|fa|چرکس}}) is sometimes applied generally to [[Peoples of the Caucasus|Caucasian peoples]] living beyond [[Derbent]] in [[Dagestan]],<ref name="ČARKAS"/> which was the northernmost principal city of Iran prior to its ceding to [[Imperial Russia|Russia]] in the first half of the 19th century following the [[Treaty of Gulistan]].
==History== Circassians in Iran have a long history. To a certain good extent, they shared the same role as their brethren who lived in neighbouring [[Ottoman Turkey]]; many were importees, deportees, slaves, but also made up many of the notable [[noble families]] in the empire, while many others were kingmakers, military commanders, soldiers, craftsmen, peasants, while they also composed many of the kings' wives and women in the [[harem]]. Under the various kings of the [[Safavid dynasty|Safavid]] and [[Qajar dynasty]], many Circassians would eventually happen to live in Iran.
===Safavids=== The first Circassian presence in Iran dates to the early [[Safavid]] era, during which [[Shaykh Junayd]] raided various regions of [[Circassia]] and carried of prisoners back.<ref name="Eskandar Beg, I, pp. 17–18">Eskandar Beg, I, pp. 17–18</ref> From the time of king (''[[shah]]'') [[Tahmasp I]] (r. 1524-1576), the Circassians started to play an important role in Iranian society,<ref name="Eskandar Beg, I, pp. 17–18"/> and began to appear as a large ethnic group in the successive empires based in Iran.
In order to make a [[counterbalance]] to the tribal, ethnic, and favoured interests the [[Qizilbash]] gave which make a system imbalanced, Tahmasp I had already been making the first steps of creating a new layer in Iranian society.<ref name="Tahmāsp I">{{cite web|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/tahmasp-i|title=Tahmāsp I|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref> The kings before Tahmasp and he himself often found themselves incapable of ruling effectively due to the extremely strong influence the Qizilbash expressed in all spheres of the empire. The Qizilbash had formed the backbone of the [[Safavid dynasty|Safaviyya]] from the earliest days, and they had always provided substantial military as well, on which the Safavids relied for a long period of time. In order to break this system, a counterbalance was needed, and a new layer in society was the medium through which this could be reached.<ref name="Tahmāsp I"/> This new layer in society, was called the "third force", as they were a new ethnic class, or "force", alongside the Turkomans and Persians. This new layer, initiated by Tahmasp I, would be composed of many hundreds of thousands of [[Christian]] and [[pagan]] Caucasian, mostly ethnically Circassian and Georgian, deportees, importees, slaves, and migrants. This new society layer was to be eventually fully accomplished and implemented by king [[Abbas I of Persia|Abbas I]] (r. 1588-1629).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/barda-v|title=BARDA and BARDA-DĀRI v. Military slavery in Islamic Iran|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> Out of this new layer, a new military force was established as well; a force that would directly contest the [[hegemony]] of the Qizilbash everywhere in the empire, replace them from all their positions, thereby firmly securing the kings' grip over the kingdom. These ''[[ghilman|gholams]]'', or "military slaves", were part of this newly created layer in society. The ''gholam'' slave system, although initiated by Tahmasp I, was perfectioned and fully implemented by king Abbas I, and its rank and file were drawn from these massive amounts of ethnic Circassians, Georgians, Armenians and other [[peoples of the Caucasus]], such as [[Lezgins]]. Eventually, these large amounts of Circassians and other Caucasians, only loyal to the shah, replaced the Qizilbash and vied through the system with them for political hegemony and supremacy, and were to be victorious,<ref name="ČARKAS"/> although sometimes they would vy against each other as well.<ref>Babaie, Sussan (2004). "Slaves of the Shah: New Elites of Safavid Iran." pp. 17, I.B.Tauris, {{ISBN|1860647219}}</ref>
Circassians made up a good bulk of these elite armies (the so-called ''gholams''), and played therefore a pivotal role. This elite [slave system] army was similar to the [[Janissaries]] of neighbouring [[Ottoman Turkey]], in its implementation and formation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/barda-v|title=BARDA and BARDA-DĀRI v. Military slavery in Islamic Iran|accessdate=25 April 2015}}</ref> The ones in the armies received, after advanced education, conversion to [[Islam]], and upbringing by Muslim families, the best military training and equipment, and were the strongest force and class of the empire. Other large amounts of Circassians were, like the Georgians, employed and deployed in all other possible aspects and positions that the empires offered, such as the [[harem]], civil administration, military administration, peasantry, and craftry, amongst others, while other large numbers were initially settled in various regions in mainland Iran, including [[Gilan province|Gilan]], [[Mazandaran province|Mazandaran]], and [[Fars Province|Fars]].
According to [[Sir Thomas Herbert, 1st Baronet|Thomas Herbert]], who was in [[Safavid dynasty|Safavid Iran]] in the first half of the 17th century, Aspas was inhabited by some 40,000 transplanted [[Christian]] [[Circassians]] and [[Georgians]].<ref>Thomas Herbert. [https://books.google.com/books?id=w41SZ-nZ8ccC&pg=PA117&dq=circassians+asupas+herbet&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=ZoZgVaTvFILP7gb1l4GgDw&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=circassians%20asupas%20herbet&f=false ''Travels in Persia: 1627-1629''] Routledge, 10 okt. 2005 {{ISBN|1134285841}} p 117</ref> By the time of king [[Suleiman I of Persia|Suleiman I]]'s reign (r. 1666–1694), an estimated 20,000 Circassians, [[Dagestan]]is, and Georgians were living in the Safavid capital of Isfahan alone.{{sfn|Matthee|2012|page=67}}
Many of the shahs, princes, and princesses descended from noble Circassian lines. Many of the Safavid nobility at the court were Circassian.<ref>Aptin Khanbaghi. [https://books.google.nl/books?id=iXUAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA130&dq=many+circassians+safavid+court&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAGoVChMIt--BwryLxgIVIyHbCh2SCwAe#v=onepage&q=many%20circassians%20safavid%20court&f=false ''The Fire, the Star and the Cross: Minority Religions in Medieval and Early Modern Iran''] I.B.Tauris, 22 February 2006 {{ISBN|0857712667}} pp. 130–131</ref> In fact, the Safavids their heavily mixed ancestry includes several Circassian lines.<ref name="Andrew J. Newman 2006, p. 41">[https://books.google.com/books?id=afsYCq1XOewC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=safavids+had+circassian+wives&source=bl&ots=iL9mMQKwc6&sig=azvDnCphLdWk8czfpGHQjpfMjFQ&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=7I4fU-frGsaGywPX4oHgCA&ved=0CGMQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=safavids%20had%20circassian%20wives&f=false.] ''Safavid Iran: Rebirth of a Persian Empire'', L.B. Tauris. 2006, p. 41.</ref><ref>Rudolph (Rudi) Matthee ''Encyclopaedia Iranica'', Columbia University, New York 2001, p. 493</ref> King [[Abbas II of Persia|Abbas II]] (r. 1642-1666) and Shah [[Suleiman I of Persia|Suleiman I]] (r. 1666-1694) are just some of the examples amongst the highest nobility that were born by Circassian mothers.
===Qajars=== Following [[Ethnic Cleansing of Circassians|the mass expulsion of the native Circassians]] of the Northwest Caucasus in 1864 mainly towards the Ottoman Empire, some also fled to neighboring [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar Iran]], which bordered the Ottoman Empire and Imperial Russia. In Iran, the government followed an assimilation policy, starting the gradual absorption of the Caucasian refugees into the population. Some of these deportees from after 1864 rose to various high ranks such as in the [[Persian Cossack Brigade]], where every member of the army was either Circassian or any other type of ethnos from the [[Caucasus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mepc.org/journal/middle-east-policy-archives/iranian-armed-forces-politics-revolution-and-war-part-one?print|title=The Iranian Armed Forces in Politics, Revolution and War: Part One|accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref>
==Modern day== Despite heavy assimilation over the centuries, Circassian settlements have lasted into the 20th century.<ref name="ČARKAS"/> However, the [[Circassian language]]s once also widely used by the large Circassian minority, no sizable number of Circassians in Iran speak the language anymore.<ref name="books.google.nl"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/georgia-iv--2 |title=Georgia viii: Georgian communities in Persia |last1=Oberling |first1=Pierre |date=7 February 2012 |website=[[Encyclopaedia Iranica]] |accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mcha.kbsu.ru/english/m_hist_01E.htm.html |title=Circassian |publisher=Official Circassian Association |accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://iranian.com/Travelers/June97/Chardin/index.shtml |title=Persians: Kind, hospitable, tolerant flattering cheats? |first1=Sir John |last1=Chardin |authorlink=Jean Chardin |date=June 1997 |journal=[[Iranian.com|The Iranian]] |accessdate=9 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970620173929/http://www.iranian.com/Travelers/June97/Chardin/index.shtml |archivedate=20 June 1997 |deadurl=no}} Excerpted from: * {{cite book |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5jPL0A31H5MC&pg=PA183#v=twopage&q&f=false |chapter=Book 2, Chapter XI: Of the Temper, Manners, and Customs of the Persians: A XVII th. Century Viewpoint |first1=Sir John |last1=Chardin |authorlink=Jean Chardin |title=Travels in Persia, 1673–1677 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5jPL0A31H5MC |location=New York |publisher=Dover Publications |year=1988 |pages=183–197 |isbn=9780486256368 |oclc=798310290 |accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref> After the Georgians, the Circassians are the second largest Caucasus derived group in Iran, comprising significant numbers.<ref name="books.google.nl"/>
==Notables== Notable Iranians of either partial or full Circassian descent include: *[[Fawzia Fuad of Egypt|Fawzia Fuad]], Empress consort of Iran (1941–1948) *Princess [[Shahnaz Pahlavi|Shahnaz]] of Iran *Princess [[Ardeshir Zahedi|Zahra Mahnaz Zahedi]] *Prince [[Khosrow Jahanbani|Keykhosrow Jahanbani]] *Princess [[Khosrow Jahanbani|Fawzia Jahanbani]] *[[Suleiman I of Persia]] *[[Teresia Sampsonia]] *[[Yusuf Agha (Circassian)|Yusuf Agha]] *[[Pari Khan Khanum]] *[[Sultan-Agha Khanum]] *[[Abbas II of Persia]] *[[Shamkhal Sultan]] *[[Nakihat Khanum]] *[[Qazaq Khan Cherkes|Qazāq Khan Cherkes]], governor of [[Shirvan]], commander of the [[Qizilbash]] ([[Karamanlu]] and Ḵeneslū divisions)<ref name="ČARKAS"/> *[[Farhad Beg|Farhad Beg Cherkes]] *[[Khvajeh Mohammad Safavi]] *[[Mohammad Baqer Mirza|Moḥammad-Bāqer Ṣafī Mīrzā]] *[[Behbud Khan Cherkes|Ūzūn Behbūd Beg]] *[[Suleiman Mirza (son of Tahmasp I)]] *[[Safi of Persia]] *[[Anna Khanum]] *[[Najafqoli Khan Cherkes]] *[[Fereydun Khan Cherkes]]
==See also== * [[Ethnicities in Iran]] * [[Circassians in Turkey]] * [[Circassians in Iraq]] * [[Circassians in Syria]] * [[Peoples of the Caucasus in Iran]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== * {{cite encyclopedia | article = ČARKAS | last = Manz | first = Beatrice | last2 = Haneda | first2 = Masashi | authorlink = | url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/carkas-cherkes-term-used-in-persian-arabic-and-turkic-for-the-circassian-people-of-the-northwest-caucasus-who-call-thems | editor-last = | editor-first = | editor-link = | encyclopedia = Encyclopaedia Iranica, Vol. IV, Fasc. 7 | pages = 816–819 | location = | publisher = | year = 1990 | isbn = |ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Matthee|first1=Rudi|title=Persia in Crisis: Safavid Decline and the Fall of Isfahan|date=2012|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1845117450|ref=harv}} *[[Roger Savory|Savory, Roger]], ''Iran Under the Safavids''; Cambridge University Press, 2007 {{ISBN|0521042518}}. *P. Oberling, "Georgians and Circassians in Iran," Studia Caucasica (The Hague) 1, 1963 *J. R. Perry, "Forced Migrations in Iran During the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries," Iranian Studies 8, 1975, pp. 199–215. *N. Falsafī, Zendagānī-e Šāh ʿAbbās-e awwal, 4 vols., Tehran, 1334-46 Š./1955-67 *Babaie, Sussan, [https://books.google.com/books?id=2BMVnw9JQh8C&printsec=frontcover&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false Slaves of the Shah: New Elites of Safavid Iran] I.B.Tauris, 15 October 2004 {{ISBN|1860647219}}

revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/23.28.232.176|23.28.232.176]] ([[User talk:23.28.232.176|talk]]) to last revision by 75.149.160.134. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Distinguish | Dickey-Wicker Amendment}} In United States politics, the '''Dickey Amendment''' is a provision first inserted as a [[rider (legislation)|rider]] into the 1996 federal government [[omnibus spending bill]] which mandated that "none of the funds made available for injury prevention and control at the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) may be used to advocate or promote [[gun control]]."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-104publ208/pdf/PLAW-104publ208.pdf|title=Public Law 104–208|last=104th Congress|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> In the same spending bill, Congress earmarked $2.6 million from the CDC's budget, the exact amount that had previously been allocated to the agency for firearms research the previous year, for [[traumatic brain injury]]-related research.<ref name=apa>{{cite web | url=http://www.apa.org/science/about/psa/2013/02/gun-violence.aspx | title=Gun violence research: History of the federal funding freeze | work=American Psychological Association | date=February 2013 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Jamieson, Christine}}</ref>
The amendment was lobbied for by the NRA. The amendment is named after its author [[Jay Dickey]], a Republican member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[Arkansas]].<ref name=apa/> Many commentators have described this amendment as a "ban" on gun violence research by the CDC.<ref name=smithsonian>{{cite web | url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/cdc-still-cant-study-causes-gun-violence-180955884/?no-ist | title=Why So Few Scientists Are Studying the Causes of Gun Violence | work=Smithsonian Magazine | date=13 July 2015 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Fessenden, Marissa}}</ref>
==Positions taken== The amendment was introduced after lobbying by the [[National Rifle Association]] in response to their perceived bias in a 1993 study by [[Arthur Kellermann]] that found that guns in the home were associated with an increased risk of [[homicide]] in the home, as well as other CDC funded studies and efforts.<ref name=apa/><ref name=huffpo/> [[Mark L. Rosenberg]], the former director of the [[National Center for Injury Prevention and Control]], has described this amendment as "a shot fired across the bow" at CDC researchers who wanted to research [[gun violence]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/their-1996-clash-shaped-the-gun-debate-for-years-now-they-want-to-reshape-it/2015/12/30/707bfed6-a8e5-11e5-bff5-905b92f5f94b_story.html | title=Their 1996 clash shaped the gun debate for years. Now they want to reshape it. | work=Washington Post | date=30 December 2015 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Frankel, Todd C.}}</ref> In a 2012 op-ed, Dickey and Rosenberg argued that the CDC should be able to research gun violence,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/we-wont-know-the-cause-of-gun-violence-until-we-look-for-it/2012/07/27/gJQAPfenEX_print.html | title=We won’t know the cause of gun violence until we look for it | work=Washington Post | date=27 July 2012 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Dickey, Jay}}</ref> and Dickey has since said that he regrets his role in stopping the CDC from researching gun violence,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/02/politics/jay-dickey-gun-violence-research/ | title=Former GOP congressman flips on support for gun violence research | work=CNN | date=2 December 2015 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Diamond, Jeremy}}</ref> saying he simply didn't want to "let any of those dollars go to gun control advocacy."<ref>https://www.npr.org/2015/10/09/447098666/ex-rep-dickey-regrets-restrictive-law-on-gun-violence-research</ref>
In response to this amendment being adopted, the [[American Psychological Association]] adopted a resolution condemning it.<ref name=apa/> In December 2015, multiple medical organizations, including [[Doctors for America]], the [[American College of Preventive Medicine]], and the [[American Academy of Pediatrics]], called on Congress to repeal the amendment.<ref name=huffpo/> That same month, the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] also called for an end to this amendment.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2015/12/08/458952821/congress-still-limits-health-research-on-gun-violence | title=Congress Still Limits Health Research On Gun Violence | work=NPR | date=8 December 2015 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Kodjak, Alison}}</ref>
==Attempts to remove the amendment== In 2013, President [[Barack Obama]] directed the CDC to research gun violence. The CDC responded by funding a research project in 2013<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog/18319/priorities-for-research-to-reduce-the-threat-of-firearm-related-violence?gclid=CjwKEAjwzN27BRDFn9aAwLmH2yISJABWuEXcG8-xLh_NaouZI4Muf0cS3__taXwWeUb0sPqaDckI6xoC7o3w_wcB|title=Priorities for Research to Reduce the Threat of Firearm-Related Violence|last=IOM (Institute of Medicine) and NRC (National Research Council)|first=|date=2013-06-05|isbn=9780309284387|doi=10.17226/18319}}</ref> and conducting their own study in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dhss.delaware.gov/dhss/dms/files/cdcgunviolencereport10315.pdf|title=Elevated Rates of Urban Firearm Violence and Opportunities for Prevention|last=Sumner|first=Steven|date=November 3, 2015|website=Elevated Rates of Urban Firearm Violence and Opportunities for Prevention|publisher=Delaware Department of Health and Social Services|access-date=July 2, 2016}}</ref> That month, a spokeswoman for the agency, Courtney Lenard, told the ''Washington Post'' that "It is possible for us to conduct firearm-related research within the context of our efforts to address youth violence, domestic violence, sexual violence, and suicide. But our resources are very limited."<ref name=huffpo>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/dickey-amendment-gun-violence-research-ban_us_56606201e4b072e9d1c4eaaa | title=Why The Ban On Gun Violence Research Is A Public Health Issue | work=Huffington Post | date=7 December 2015 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Schumaker, Erin}}</ref>
In October 2015, 110 members of Congress, all of whom were Democrats, signed a letter calling on Congress to reject the amendment.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/10/28/110-members-of-congress-plead-for-ending-ban-on-cdc-gun-research/ | title=110 members of Congress plead for ending ban on CDC gun research | work=Washington Post | date=28 October 2015 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Frankel, Todd C.}}</ref>
In December 2015, despite [[Nancy Pelosi]]'s efforts to have the Dickey amendment removed from the spending bill for the following year, Congress passed this bill with the amendment still in it.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/263404-house-dems-lose-fight-to-nix-gun-research-ban-in-budget | title=House Dems lose fight to nix gun research ban in budget | work=The Hill | date=16 December 2015 | accessdate=13 March 2016 | author=Ferris, Sarah}}</ref>
On March 21, 2018, Congressional negotiators reached a deal on an Omnibus continuing resolution. The 1.3 trillion dollar spending agreement also includes language that codified Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar interpretation of the Dickey Rider in testimony on February 18, 2018, before the US House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/02/15/alex-azar-cdc-gun-violence-research-414977 | title=Trump’s new health chief backs CDC research on gun violence | work=Politico | date=18 February 2018 | accessdate=22 March 2018 | author=Cancryn, Adam.}}</ref> While the amendment itself remains, the language in a report accompanying the Omnibus spending bill clarifies that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention can conduct research into gun violence, but cannot use government appropriated funds to do so.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2018/03/22/heres-what-congress-is-stuffing-into-its-1-3-trillion-spending-bill/ | title=Here’s what Congress is stuffing into its $1.3 trillion spending bill | work=Washington Post | date=22 March 2018 | accessdate=22 March 2018 | authors=DeBonis, Mike, O'Keefe, Ed, and Werner, Erica.}}</ref> It was signed into law by U.S. President Donald J. Trump on March 23, 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2018/03/23/trump-threatens-to-veto-omnibus-bill-because-it-does-not-address-daca-recipients | title=Trump signs $1.3 trillion spending bill despite veto threat on Twitter | work=Washington Post | date=23 March 2018 | accessdate=26 March 2018 | author=Wagner, John and DeBonis, Mike.}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Gun law in the United States]] *[[Gun politics in the United States]] *[[Gun violence in the United States]] *[[Tiahrt Amendment]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
